title: The Lilac Sunbonnet: A Love Story
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: His uncle Agnew, the Lady Elizabeth's childlessbrother, who for the sake of the favour of a strongly Protestantaunt had left the mother church of the Greatorix family, had beenexpected to do something for Agnew; but up to this present time hehad received only his name from him, in lieu of all the statelyheritages of Holywood in the Nith Valley hard by Lincluden, andStennesholm in Carrick.

title: My first visit to Europe:
author: Dickinson, Andrew
snippet: Holywood seemed a sit name for an angelic abode.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: On our journey to Amsterdam we passvast green flats, on which are many cattle, and on all sides windmills ;odours not very refreshing, sometimes like a whiff of the Blackstaff inBelfast or the banks at Holywood; trim little houses, with much woodin their construction ; tall roofs and large windows with many smallpanes; and country women without hats or bonnets, but with theirlaced caps, golden frontlets like peg-tops turned upside down, skull caps,and earrings, all cheery and contented-looking.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: line, which then went no farther than Holywood.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: I remember the first sod beingcut for the railway, and the first train starting from Holywood, when thenavvies blocked the way until they got money to drink prosperity to the

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: Holywood is a very fashionable village aboutmidway between Bangor and Belfast, called so from being in ancienttimes the wood round the monastery or church, and considered holy;but it is now pronounced Hollywood, for which there is no meaning.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: Thesail up the lough is very fine, having handsome residences on either side,with the town of Carrickfergus, with its old castle, on one side, andHolywood and Bangor on the other.
